Chrissy Gonzalez

Legal Documents for Startups

Early-stage companies often keep haphazard legal records, an expensive mistake many founders don’t discover until they get funded and have to pay a lawyer to straighten things out. In my current role, I’m helping to design a tool for entrepreneurs to get organized, legally, from the earliest moment possible.

Sketches

When I joined the project, a basic concept had been outlined, but most of the details were still to be determined. Through brainstorms and discussions, the idea of a ‘workflow’ emerged as the core of the product — the entrepreneur chooses to undertake a workflow, enters a minimal amount of information, and through the magic of technology, appropriate legal documents are produced. But what are the exact tasks available, what information is required, what documents are produced, and how should it all be organized? Many sketches ensued.

Workflow sketches

Thumbnail Wireframes

When I moved from sketches to wireframes, it immediately became obvious how differently we defined our shared terminology. This period became about examining our own assumptions and redefining a model for how the product worked. Because we were still thinking at a high level, I tried to keep the wireframes at a lower fidelity.

First steps in designing the workflow wizard

Higher-Fidelity Wireframes

After making some progress, I started designing at actual size with existing styles from the Gust core product. During this period I looked more closely at the lists of documents, and we added a second workflow for documenting a relationship, both of which revealed a few gaps in our thinking.

More refined wireframes

Revised Wizard

The small, in-page document wizard helped us make decisions and approach document creation in a modular way, but it started to break down when we tried to accommodate more complicated document types. I explored different ideas for a full-page wizard, and we chose this one as the most extensible. (The core product styles were being updated around this time, so this version also incorporates the latest look and feel.)

With each iteration, the workflow wizard becomes more robust and able to represent more complex information, but there’s still a lot to do. Ideally, the next steps in our design process will include testing this version with entrepreneurs and iterating to add capabilities and address useful feedback.
